raw_text:
Box office blow for Alexander
 
 Director Oliver Stone's historical epic Alexander has failed in its bid to conquer the box office, entering the US film charts at number six.
 
 The swords and sandals blockbuster, rumoured to have cost more than $150m (£79m) to make, earned just $13.5 (£7m) over three days at the US box office. Due to the Thanksgiving holiday, the film opened on Wednesday, bringing its total takings to $21.6m (£11.4m). Top of the box office for a second week was action movie National Treasure. The family adventure, starring Nicolas Cage, took $33.1m (£17.m), ahead of animated comedy The Incredibles - now in its fourth week in the charts - which took $24.1m (£12.7m).
 
 Last week Oliver Stone's film met with scathing reviews from US critics. The film stars Irish actor Colin Farrell as one of history's most celebrated leaders - a relentless and arrogant warrior who conquered much of the known world by the age of 25. In particular, its portrayal of Alexander as a bisexual has met with a hostile reception and the threat of legal action from Greek lawyers. "Though the battles have the blood-and-sinew bravado you expect from Oliver Stone, this three-hour buttnumbathon is hamstrung by a hectoring grandiosity," wrote one reviewer in Rolling Stone magazine. Others poured scorn on Farrell's bleached hair and Angelina Jolie's unwieldy accent, which Variety called "a combination of Mata Hari and Count Dracula" . But novelist Gore Vidal defended the film, saying it was "barrier-breaking" for its frank depiction of bisexuality.
 
 In Sweden last Thursday, to pick up a lifetime achievement award at the Stockholm International Film Festival, Stone expressed the hope that Alexander might be better appreciated in Europe. "One of the reasons I am being honoured here is Europeans tend to see me a little differently than they do in the US," said the director behind JFK, Platoon and Born on the Fourth of July. He added Alexander "was not an easy movie, but then I've never made easy movies".
llama3.2:1b: Alexander has failed at the US box office, earning $13.5m over three days with a total of $21.6m after opening on Wednesday due to Thanksgiving holidays. The film cost $150m to make and received negative reviews from US critics, who criticized its portrayal of Alexander as bisexual and excessive grandiosity. Despite this, novelist Gore Vidal defended the film, saying it was "barrier-breaking" for frank depictions of bisexuality.
llama3.2:3b: Alexander, directed by Oliver Stone, failed to conquer the box office, earning $21.6m (£11.4m) in its opening week, despite scathing US critic reviews and a high production cost of over $150m. The film's portrayal of Alexander as bisexual has sparked hostility from Greek lawyers, while it was well-received by Gore Vidal.
gemma2:2b: Oliver Stone's historical epic "Alexander" opened at number six in the US box office with a disappointing gross of $21.6 million. The film faced negative reviews for its portrayal of Alexander as bisexual and has been criticized for various aspects like Colin Farrell's appearance and Angelina Jolie's accent.  Despite the criticism, director Oliver Stone hopes that the film will be appreciated more in Europe.
qwen2.5:0.5b: Alexander failed to make money at the box office, which is why it's now number six on the global film charts. It's an action comedy starring Nicolas Cage as a former Greek warrior who conquered much of the known world by age 25. Some critics called it "barrier-breaking" for its frank depiction of bisexuality, but Warner Bros. said they were happy with the outcome and would continue to release the film in theaters.
qwen2.5:1.5b: Oliver Stone's historical epic Alexander failed at the box office with earnings of $13.5 million in three days, opening number six in US charts after a September 18th release coinciding with Thanksgiving. Competing action film National Treasure topped week-long box office rankings with $33.1 million and animated comedy The Incredibles followed closely behind at $24.1 million. Director Stone's controversial depiction of Alexander as bisexual, met with harsh reviews and criticism from the media.
qwen2.5:3b: Director Oliver Stone's historical epic Alexander failed to perform well at the US box office, entering at number six despite a reported $150m production cost. The film earned just $13.5m over three days and was surpassed by action movie National Treasure in its second week. Critics largely criticized the film for its portrayal of Alexander as bisexual and Farrell's performance, while novelist Gore Vidal defended it. Stone hopes Alexander will be better appreciated in Europe where he is seen differently from critics in the US.

Despite the dire weather it faced, the film met with a plethora of reviews from critics and audiences alike. The director of the movie Oliver Stone's narrative is one of his greatest achievements, making the film a timeless classic of film history.
smollm:1.7b:
The summary should preserve key ideas and details:

1. Oliver Stone's historical epic Alexander has failed in its bid to conquer the box office, entering the US film charts at number six.
2. The swords and sandals blockbuster, rumoured to have cost more than $150m (£79m) to make, earned just $13.5 (£7m) over three days at the US box office.
3. Due to the Thanksgiving holiday, the film opened on Wednesday, bringing its total takings to $21.6m (£11.4m). Top of the box office for a second week was action movie National Treasure. The family adventure, starring Irish actor Colin Farrell as one of history's most celebrated leaders - a relentless and arrogant warrior who conquered much of the known world by the age of 25 - met with scathing reviews from US critics.
4. Oliver Stone's film met with scathing reviews from US critics. The film stars Irish actor Colin Farrell as one of history's most celebrated leaders - a relentless and arrogant warrior who conquered much of the known world by the age of 25 - but was also criticized for its portrayal of bisexuality.
5. Last week Oliver Stone's film met with scathing reviews from US critics, who praised the film's bold depiction of bisexuality but were also critical of its handling of the subject matter.
6. The film's portrayal of Alexander as a bisexual has been widely criticized by some reviewers, who have accused the film of being overly focused on the character's sexual orientation and not doing enough to explore other aspects of his life and personality.
7. Oliver Stone defended his film, saying it was "barrier-breaking" for its frank depiction of bisexuality in a Western context. He added that Europeans tend to see him a little differently than they do in the US, where he has made many films.
8. The film's box office performance has been mixed, with Oliver Stone reportedly feeling pressure from his producers to make a more commercial film. Despite this, the film has still managed to attract a significant following among fans of historical epics and action movies.

tinydolphin:1.1b:
The film 'Alexander' by Oliver Stone has underwhelmed in the US box office. Despite costing $150m (£79m), the historical epic only managed to gather a measly $13.5m in its opening weekend, which is far below expectations for an Oscar-winning film. 

The movie has been met with harsh reviews by US critics who have accused it of being overblown and portraying Alexander as a bisexual warrior. One critic even wrote that the film's portrayal of Alexander is "a combination of Mata Hari and Count Dracula." Despite its underwhelming performance, director Oliver Stone has expressed hope that the movie will be better appreciated in Europe.
